Authors:
Valeria Souza, Alejandra Moreno-Letelier, Michael
Travisano, Luis D Alcaraz, Gabriela Olmedo-Alvarez, Luis E Eguiarte
Title:
The lost world of Cuatro Cienegas Basin, a relictual
bacterial niche in a desert oasis.
Keywords:
Cuatro Cienegas, biodiversity, bacterial ecology, 16s,
phosphorous
Abstract:
Barriers to immigration can lead to localized adaptive
radiations and increased endemism. We propose that extreme oligotrophy
can be a strong barrier to immigration over geological timescales and
facilitate the evolution of highly coevolved and very diverse microbial
communities. We show that the endangered oasis of Cuatro Ci√©negas Basin
can be a model for a lost world, where the ancient niche of extreme
oligotrophy favored survival of ancestral microorganisms that persisted
due to environmental stability and low extinction rates.
Diversification/extinction rates in Bacillus showed several CCB endemic
clades that diverged from the rest of Bacillus spp. in different times
of the Paleozoic and Mesozoic, in contrast to more recent Bacillus,
Clostridium and Bacteroidetes lineages. CCB conservation is vital to the
understanding of early evolutionary and ecological processes.
